Regulation Title: Securitisation Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Supervisory Authorities EBA, ESMA, EIOPA
Description: Created a new, comprehensive legal framework for securitisation in the EU. It sets out duediligence, riskretention, and transparency requirements for all parties involved in a securitisation and establishes criteria for Simple, Transparent and Standardised STS securitisations.
Impact: Aimed to revive the EU securitisation market postfinancial crisis by creating a safer and more transparent framework, thereby improving funding channels for the real economy.

Regulation Title: Financial Sector Regulation Act South Africa
Regulatory Body: South African Reserve Bank / Financial Sector Conduct Authority FSCA
Description: A landmark law that fundamentally reformed the financial regulatory structure in South Africa by establishing a "Twin Peaks" model. It created a dedicated prudential regulator the Prudential Authority and a dedicated market conduct regulator the FSCA.
Impact: Created a more proactive and specialized regulatory system designed to improve financial stability and strengthen consumer protection and market integrity.

Regulation Title: Money Market Funds MMF Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Established new, uniform rules for all money market funds in the EU to make them more resilient to market shocks. It introduced new fund categories e.g., Low Volatility NAV and imposed liquidity and diversification requirements.
Impact: Increased the stability of the MMF sector, a key source of shortterm funding for the economy. Required significant restructuring of existing MMF products.

Regulation Title: Prospectus Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Replaced the 2003 Prospectus Directive to simplify the rules for companies, especially SMEs, when issuing securities and raising capital in the EU. It introduced a new, shorter EU Growth prospectus.
Impact: Aimed to make it easier and cheaper for companies to access public markets, thereby fostering capital market union.

Regulation Title: Shareholder Rights Directive II SRD II European Union
Regulatory Body: European Commission / National Competent Authorities
Description: A directive aimed at improving corporate governance in listed companies by enhancing shareholder engagement. It introduced new rules on the identification of shareholders, transmission of information, "say on pay" for directors' remuneration, and related party transactions.
Impact: Increased transparency between companies and their shareholders, empowered investors to have a greater say in corporate matters, especially executive pay, and improved oversight of related party deals.

Regulation Title: Law on Reserved Alternative Investment Funds RAIF Luxembourg
Regulatory Body: Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier CSSF / Luxembourg Parliament
Description: Introduced a new, highly flexible type of alternative investment fund AIF that is not subject to direct supervision by the CSSF. Instead, a RAIF must appoint a fully authorized Alternative Investment Fund Manager AIFM, which is itself regulated.
Impact: Created a hugely popular and successful fund product by offering a quicker timetomarket and lower regulatory burden than other supervised funds, while maintaining investor protection through the regulation of the manager.

Regulation Title: Benchmarks Regulation BMR European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A regulation introduced in response to scandals involving the manipulation of interest rate benchmarks like LIBOR. It establishes a common framework to ensure the accuracy and integrity of benchmarks used in financial instruments and contracts in the EU.
Impact: Imposed stringent governance and control requirements on benchmark administrators, contributors, and users. Led to a transition away from older benchmarks like LIBOR to new, more robust reference rates.

Regulation Title: Act on the Corporate Governance of Financial Companies South Korea
Regulatory Body: Financial Services Commission FSC
Description: A dedicated law that consolidated and strengthened corporate governance requirements specifically for financial companies. It mandated stricter qualification criteria for executives, enhanced the role and independence of the board of directors, and improved internal control systems.
Impact: Aimed to improve the soundness and transparency of management in the Korean financial sector, which was seen as critical for overall financial stability and consumer protection.

Regulation Title: SEBI Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements Regulations, 2015 LODR India
Regulatory Body: Securities and Exchange Board of India SEBI
Description: A new, comprehensive framework that consolidated and streamlined the provisions of various listing agreements for different securities. It created a single set of compliance requirements for all listed entities.
Impact: Simplified the compliance landscape for listed companies in India, improved corporate governance standards, and enhanced the quality and timeliness of disclosures to investors.

Regulation Title: Financial Market Infrastructure Act FMIA Switzerland
Regulatory Body: Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority FINMA
Description: A comprehensive law that regulates financial market infrastructures like trading venues and central counterparties and derivatives trading, aligning Swiss regulation with international standards e.g., EMIR, MiFID.
Impact: Modernized Swiss financial market regulation, particularly for derivatives, ensuring its equivalence with EU rules and maintaining international market access.

Regulation Title: Japan's Corporate Governance Code Japan
Regulatory Body: Tokyo Stock Exchange TSE / Financial Services Agency FSA
Description: A code of principles for effective corporate governance for listed companies in Japan. It operates on a "comply or explain" basis, requiring companies to either adhere to its principles e.g., appointing independent directors or explain why they have not.
Impact: Significantly improved corporate governance standards in Japan, leading to increased board independence, better engagement with shareholders, and a greater focus on capital efficiency and shareholder returns.

Regulation Title: Extractive Sector Transparency Measures Act ESTMA Canada
Regulatory Body: Natural Resources Canada
Description: A law requiring oil, gas, and mining companies subject to Canadian law to publicly disclose, on an annual basis, specific payments made to all governments in Canada and abroad.
Impact: Increased transparency and aimed to deter corruption in the extractive sector globally. Provided citizens of resourcerich countries with information to hold their governments accountable for revenues generated from natural resources.

Regulation Title: European LongTerm Investment Funds ELTIF Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Created a new type of collective investment vehicle designed to channel capital towards European longterm investments in the real economy, such as infrastructure projects or SMEs. It has specific rules on eligible assets, diversification, and marketing.
Impact: Aimed to boost nonbank financing for the European economy by creating a dedicated fund structure for longterm, illiquid assets, though initial uptake was slower than anticipated before a later revision.

Regulation Title: SEBI Prohibition of Insider Trading Regulations, 2015 India
Regulatory Body: Securities and Exchange Board of India SEBI
Description: A complete replacement of the 1992 regulations, establishing a new, more robust framework to curb insider trading. It widened the definition of "insider" and "unpublished price sensitive information."
Impact: Strengthened the legal and enforcement framework against insider trading, bringing it in line with global best practices and increasing compliance requirements for listed companies and insiders.

Regulation Title: Disclosure of Women on Boards and in Executive Positions Comply or Explain Canada
Regulatory Body: Canadian Securities Administrators CSA
Description: A rule requiring most listed companies to disclose annually, on a "comply or explain" basis, their policies regarding the representation of women on their board and in executive officer positions, as well as their targets and actual numbers.
Impact: Significantly increased the transparency around gender diversity in Canadian corporate leadership, leading to a notable increase in the number of women appointed to boards of directors.

Regulation Title: Packaged Retail and Insurancebased Investment Products PRIIPs Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Supervisory Authorities EBA, EIOPA, ESMA
Description: Requires manufacturers of PRIIPs to produce a standardized Key Information Document KID for retail investors. The KID provides essential information about the product's nature, risks, and costs in a simple, comparable format.
Impact: Increased transparency and comparability of complex investment products for retail investors. Created significant compliance and datagathering challenges for product manufacturers.

Regulation Title: Central Securities Depositories Regulation CSDR European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A regulation aimed at harmonizing the authorization and supervision of Central Securities Depositories CSDs across the EU and improving the safety and efficiency of securities settlement. It introduced mandatory buyins and cash penalties for settlement fails.
Impact: Increased the safety and efficiency of settlement in the EU. The settlement discipline regime imposed significant operational changes and potential costs on market participants for failing to settle trades on time.

Regulation Title: Interim Measures for the Supervision and Administration of Private Investment Funds China
Regulatory Body: China Securities Regulatory Commission CSRC
Description: The first comprehensive, departmentlevel regulation governing China's massive private funds industry. It established a registration system for private fund managers and custodians, set basic standards of conduct, and outlined fundraising rules.
Impact: Brought the previously unregulated and chaotic private funds sector under formal supervision, providing a foundation for its regulated growth while aiming to curb illegal fundraising and protect investors.

Regulation Title: Undertakings for Collective Investment in Transferable Securities V UCITS V European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A directive focused on strengthening investor protection for UCITS funds. It introduced new rules on the duties and liability of depositaries, remuneration policies for fund managers, and a harmonized regime for administrative sanctions.
Impact: Enhanced the security of assets held by UCITS funds and improved fund governance by aligning manager incentives with investor interests.

Regulation Title: Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II MiFID II European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A comprehensive overhaul of EU financial markets regulation, replacing MiFID I. It introduced stricter rules on investor protection, transparency pre and posttrade, and algorithmic trading, and unbundled research from execution fees.
Impact: Increased operational costs for financial firms, enhanced market transparency, and shifted the business model for investment research.

Regulation Title: Market Abuse Regulation MAR European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Established a common EU regulatory framework on insider dealing, unlawful disclosure of inside information, and market manipulation. It expanded the scope to cover more financial instruments and trading venues.
Impact: Strengthened market integrity and investor protection. Increased compliance burdens regarding the handling of inside information and disclosure of managers' transactions.

Regulation Title: Japan's Stewardship Code Japan
Regulatory Body: Financial Services Agency FSA
Description: A set of principles for institutional investors to fulfill their stewardship responsibilities. It encourages investors to engage actively with their investee companies to promote sustainable growth and enhance longterm corporate value.
Impact: Fostered a culture of constructive engagement between investors and corporate management in Japan, contributing to improvements in corporate governance and a greater focus on shareholder interests.

Regulation Title: Financial Markets Conduct Act 2013 New Zealand
Regulatory Body: Financial Markets Authority FMA
Description: A landmark piece of legislation that created a single, comprehensive framework for the regulation of financial products and services in New Zealand. It replaced several older acts, including the Securities Act 1978, and introduced a new licensing regime and fair dealing provisions.
Impact: Modernized New Zealand's entire financial markets landscape, making the law more accessible and principlesbased. It aimed to build investor confidence and support the development of capital markets.

Regulation Title: Companies Act, 2013 India
Regulatory Body: Ministry of Corporate Affairs
Description: A landmark piece of legislation that replaced the nearly 60yearold Companies Act of 1956. It introduced significant changes in corporate governance, disclosure norms, and shareholder rights, including classaction lawsuits.
Impact: Fundamentally changed India's corporate landscape by introducing stricter governance standards, enhancing accountability, and empowering minority shareholders.

Regulation Title: Senior Managers and Certification Regime SMCR United Kingdom
Regulatory Body: Financial Conduct Authority FCA & Prudential Regulation Authority PRA
Description: A regime designed to increase individual accountability in the financial services sector. It requires firms to map out responsibilities for senior managers and ensure that other key staff are certified as "fit and proper" for their roles.
Impact: Placed a greater burden of responsibility on senior individuals within financial firms, aiming to change the culture and reduce misconduct. Increased personal liability and compliance costs.

Regulation Title: Future of Financial Advice FoFA Reforms Australia
Regulatory Body: Australian Securities and Investments Commission ASIC
Description: A package of reforms aimed at improving the quality of financial advice and protecting retail investors. Key measures included a duty for advisors to act in the best interests of their clients, a ban on conflicted remuneration structures e.g., commissions, and enhanced disclosure requirements.
Impact: Fundamentally changed the business model for financial advice in Australia, shifting it towards a feeforservice model and increasing the professional and ethical standards required of advisors.

Regulation Title: SEBI Alternative Investment Funds Regulations, 2012 India
Regulatory Body: Securities and Exchange Board of India SEBI
Description: The first comprehensive regulatory framework for private pooled investment funds in India. It categorized AIFs e.g., venture capital, private equity, hedge funds and established a registration, investment conditions, and disclosure regime for them.
Impact: Brought India's large and growing private funds industry under a formal regulatory umbrella, enhancing transparency and investor protection, and providing a clear framework for capital formation outside of public markets.

Regulation Title: European Market Infrastructure Regulation EMIR European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A regulation designed to increase the stability of the overthecounter OTC derivative markets. It mandates central clearing for standardized OTC derivatives and reporting of all derivative contracts.
Impact: Reduced systemic risk in the financial system by making OTC derivatives markets more transparent and safer. Imposed significant reporting and clearing costs on market participants.

Regulation Title: Short Selling Regulation European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Created a harmonized EU framework for short selling and certain aspects of credit default swaps. It introduced transparency requirements reporting of significant net short positions and "locate" rules.
Impact: Increased transparency of short selling activities and gave regulators powers to intervene in exceptional situations, aiming to curb perceived market abuses.

Regulation Title: Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive AIFMD European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: A comprehensive regulatory framework for managers of alternative investment funds AIFs, such as hedge funds and private equity funds. It establishes rules for authorization, ongoing operation, transparency, and the marketing of AIFs across the EU.
Impact: Increased regulatory oversight and operational costs for alternative fund managers. Enhanced investor protection and provided a "passport" for marketing funds to professional investors throughout the EU.

Regulation Title: CVM Instruction 480 Brazil
Regulatory Body: Comissão de Valores Mobiliários CVM
Description: A comprehensive rule that completely reformulated the regime for registration of securities issuers in Brazil. It established the "Reference Form" Formulário de Referência, a detailed annual report containing extensive corporate governance, risk, and financial information.
Impact: Significantly increased the level of transparency and disclosure required from publicly listed companies in Brazil, bringing local standards much closer to international best practices.

Regulation Title: Capital Markets and Services Act 2007 CMSA Malaysia
Regulatory Body: Securities Commission Malaysia
Description: A comprehensive piece of legislation that consolidated three separate laws Securities Industry Act 1983, Futures Industry Act 1993, and Part IV of the Companies Act 1965 into a single, cohesive framework governing the Malaysian capital markets.
Impact: Modernized Malaysia's capital markets framework, streamlined licensing regimes, enhanced investor protection, and provided a clearer legal foundation for market regulation and enforcement.

Regulation Title: Financial Investment Services and Capital Markets Act FSCMA South Korea
Regulatory Body: Financial Services Commission FSC
Description: A landmark act that consolidated multiple capital marketrelated laws into a single, comprehensive statute. It adopted a more functional and principlebased regulatory approach, covering all financial investment products.
Impact: Modernized and streamlined South Korea's capital markets regulation, fostering the development of new financial products and increasing competition among financial institutions.

Regulation Title: Companies Act 2006 United Kingdom
Regulatory Body: Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy
Description: A comprehensive codification and reform of UK company law. It codified directors' duties, simplified company formation, and enhanced shareholder rights and corporate reporting requirements.
Impact: Modernized UK corporate law, making it more accessible and flexible. Increased the focus on directors' responsibilities and corporate governance.

Regulation Title: Financial Instruments and Exchange Act FIEA Japan
Regulatory Body: Financial Services Agency FSA
Description: A major overhaul of Japan's securities laws, integrating several disparate laws into a single comprehensive framework. It expanded investor protection rules to a wider range of financial products.
Impact: Created a more comprehensive and crosssectoral regulatory framework, enhancing investor protection and adapting to the convergence of financial products.

Regulation Title: National Instrument 45106 Prospectus Exemptions Canada
Regulatory Body: Canadian Securities Administrators CSA
Description: A harmonized rule that provides a comprehensive set of exemptions from the requirement to file a prospectus when distributing securities. It includes key exemptions like the accredited investor and private issuer exemptions.
Impact: Standardized and simplified the rules for raising capital in the private markets across Canada, making it easier and less costly for businesses, particularly startups and SMEs, to secure funding.

Regulation Title: Transparency Directive European Union
Regulatory Body: European Securities and Markets Authority ESMA
Description: Harmonized requirements for the disclosure of periodic and ongoing information for securities issuers whose securities are admitted to trading on a regulated market.
Impact: Increased transparency in EU capital markets by ensuring timely and regular disclosure of financial information, benefiting investors and market integrity.

Regulation Title: CLERP 9 Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Audit Reform and Corporate Disclosure Act 2004 Australia
Regulatory Body: Australian Securities and Investments Commission ASIC
Description: A significant package of reforms in response to global corporate collapses like Enron. It enhanced auditor independence, improved corporate disclosure, and strengthened the powers of the regulator.
Impact: Bolstered investor confidence by improving the quality and reliability of financial reporting and strengthening corporate governance and audit oversight.

Regulation Title: National Instrument 51102 Continuous Disclosure Obligations Canada
Regulatory Body: Canadian Securities Administrators CSA
Description: A foundational rule that harmonized and standardized the continuous disclosure requirements for reporting issuers across all Canadian provinces and territories. It covers financial statements, management discussion & analysis MD&A, and material change reports.
Impact: Created a unified national standard for corporate disclosure, reducing compliance costs for companies listed on multiple Canadian exchanges and ensuring consistent information for investors nationwide.

Regulation Title: Securities and Futures Ordinance SFO Hong Kong
Regulatory Body: Securities and Futures Commission SFC
Description: A comprehensive ordinance that consolidated and modernized 10 separate ordinances governing Hong Kong's securities and futures markets. It introduced a new licensing regime and stricter market misconduct rules.
Impact: Created a clearer, more robust regulatory framework, enhancing the SFC's powers and aligning Hong Kong's regime with international standards.

Regulation Title: Financial Advisory and Intermediary Services Act FAIS Act South Africa
Regulatory Body: Financial Sector Conduct Authority FSCA
Description: Established a comprehensive regulatory framework for the financial advisory industry to protect consumers. It requires licensing of financial service providers and imposes duties of care and disclosure.
Impact: Professionalized the financial advice industry, increased transparency, and provided greater protection for consumers of financial products.
